data.text: @dan_mill_1 @Brandon_DaS https://t.co/G446KeOsqt
@coryworon @ZanVetter Yes. More than one thing can be a problem at once.
@dinicTWN @calphonso I still remember those 5 a.m. wake-up calls. Strength to you. And also coffee. Lots of coffee.

.@calphonso: "Time to wake up."

Our 7yo: "We just woke up yesterday."
@cselley I saw a u10 team today.
@ZanVetter For sure. House is great. This is still part of youth hockey, though.
@Wardo22 I am 100 per cent going to write my next book on this subject. It will sell approximately six copies, but I will make my point.

@ZanVetter Totally agree it’s not just one *thing* about it. But suits are both a symbol of the issue and a real-world cost.

Private academies. Equipment. It’s all part of it.

@ZanVetter Hockey is at a crossroads. Either it can continue marching toward becoming an insular pursuit for those with means, or it can make meaningful strides to becoming more inclusive and accessible.

It’s a game, not a board meeting.
@67sound Gonna make sure my kid’s Grade 6 class all wear suits to their next big math test, too

RT @SeanFitz_Gerald: “I don’t think he gave a shit about the team”

Harold Ballard’s turbulent Leafs tenure: Jason Priestley digs deep in n…

@Brandon_DaS It’s a sandwich board advertisement for elitism in youth sport. Also: Like, what’s the point? Even the NHL is finally moving away from that.

It’s a game, not a graduation.

Almost nothing makes me roll my eyes harder than when a minor hockey team walks into the rink wearing suits. 

Eyes go rolling like wheels in a slot machine.
